This was a puckering sour that met my expectations, which were quite high

Pure assault on the taste buds. Lots of lemon, some pineapple, coconut. The most sour beer Ive ever had. Probably just easier to drink vinegar from the grocery store. Why do I like that? Im not sure. Probably the same reason I eat things that are too spicy. Great beer. Awesome to try.

Pours a beautiful golden apricot color with a thin creamy white head. Smells of an authentic gueuze, beautiful. Rich, sweet, sour, fresh. This nears the perfection of Drie Fonteinen. Buttery, silky, creamy smells mingle with crisp, sour apricots, apples, blood orange.  That juicy, zesty sweetness brings an exciting twist, not something I would expect from Brussels. Mouth-watering, though, and shows the terroir of the first true American lambic Ive ever smelled. Onto the palate and POW! That mouthfeel is intense. Carbonation is extremely fine, no fizz, more of a soft tingle accompanied by the punch of sourness. Again, big juicy apricot and blood orange are the surprising and welcome elements of this beer. This is the real deal. The flavors are intense, lambic-like certainly, but with their own dazzle. Rich, buttery, fruity. Beautiful sour raspberries appear as the beer opens up. As I drink it today, April 2013, this bottle (750ml batch #003) has lost some of its springy carbonation, but its safely among the best sour ales made today. The first true American lambic worthy of that name.
An American sour as good as lambic? Oh Hell yes. Fuck you, Belgium. If we could brew a decent tripel, wed have no use for you.  Dry and sparkling and deeply funky and wild. Very good beer. Drink it.

Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a small, creamy, white head. Aroma has funk, citric, light funk, some oak. Grapes and light lactic. Low carbonation, very dry and mild oily mouthfeel. Flavour has lots of citric tartness, oak dryness, orange peel, grapefruit, light funk. Sticks a lot to my teeth. Very nice.

Batch 5 375mL pours a clear golden/orange with a small white head. Aroma of funky Brett, lemon, grapefruit, white wine, and oak. Taste is sharp acidic puckering sourness and tartness, funky, white pepper, lemon zest, grapefruit, white wine oak, with an earthy dry finish. Lively and complex, delicious!!
Poured from a 375ml bottle. Huge thanks to Craig. Notes of citrus, acidic, lemon, earthy, wild. Very good, thanks Craig.

Bottled 1/10/12: Easily one of the best sour ales I have ever had. Immaculately complex. Clean and snappy. Interesting elements of tart citrus (lemon, sour cherries, grapefruit) and faint funk. Hints of white wine and oak. Extremely bold yet refined sourness. Fresh yeast esters from start to finish, and well into the aftertaste. Amazing beer. Must. Get. More.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2013 Batch 2 and 5. Shared with Mathieu87.
Appearance: not much foam, but the scent of geuze comes your way when pouring.
Nose: geuze, wine, summer-like, fresh, horse blanket, citrus. Batch 2 seemed to have more herbs and less of geuze.
Taste: amazing beer! nice sour, white wine

Altogether very good beer, thx Joris for sharing!
Pours a nice golden color. Very nice yeast tart taste with a sweet cherry afyer taste.
Aroma of apricot, citrus zest, band aid funk and slight champagne.  Pours hazy peach with no head.  Taste is citrussy with nice apricot, acetone, cellar funk and citrus peel.

Comparison with Batch 002 and Batch 005. Small white rim over hazy orange-yellow beer. Brett/lambicnose - excellent. Perfumy and citrus-filled. Batch 005 more expressly lemon, 002 more restrained. Citrus, vinous qualities in abundance. White winecharacter as Chardonnay, and more lemon (005). Batch 002 has some maltcharacter, milder. Sharp, spritzy, effervescent. Refreshing as few, even when the 002 has this less, of course, seen its age. Yet another one of Vinnies masterpieces. Probably more lambicky than the 001, but the admiration is equal.

(bottle - corked & caged 375 ml - Night of the Titans 2013) Golden pour with a very mild white head. Huge sour and funky aroma with loads of oaky sweetness and tart notes. Flavor really takes the breath away. Monster sour bomb. Tons of tart and funky Brett notes with a light sweetness at the end. Fantastic.

Awesome beer, funky lemony aroma, über aromatic, a bit wine like... Sick flavor, Bretty lemony, wine like, white wine, dryish, amazing... Fairly lively medium body, acidic, fairly easy to drink... Flavorful...

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2014 Batch 5. Dry, efflorescent, funky, huge citrus and lemon. Sticky on the palate. Barnyard funk and hay, grassy. Puckering as hell; this has gotten much more sour since its release. Smells like an aged gueuze. A damn fine sour.

Sample courtesy of QueenHolly:
Hazy, brassy gold....no head.
Scent is strongly wooden,white grape sour.
Musty, funky, vinegar.
Interesting balances...sweet at the tip of the tongue, sour at the back.
Superb.
005.  Lemon and sugar in the scent light funk. Lactic sour. Medium sourness, woodym, herbal, and spicy flavor. Still tons of citrus and lemon. Fuckin awesome.

Bottle thanks to Kan. Glowing gold pour with smallish white head. Aroma is fairly fruity, apricot skins, stonefruit, very bretty, light leathery character. Taste is sour, ever so slightly acetic but otherwise quite belgian lambic in character. Palate is medium bodied with good carbonation. Very tasty.

Bottle 375ml. [Batch 5]
Pours clear blond with low white head. Some lacing. Aroma is of citrus, fruits, vinegar, bretts, very sligth barnyard. Taste is of sourness, sourness, sourness, fruits, some very sligth barnyard. Palate: pretty dry mouthfeel. Overall: Too much sourness for me in there, almost like vinegar. Still good, nice brett action.

Bière blond quasi opaque. Arôme: "barnyard", vinaigre, fruits, bretts et agrumes. Goût acétique, surête, qui arrache. On aime ça! Belle complexité. Bière asséchante.  Parfaite pour les amateurs du style!

Bottle (375 ml) batch 005. Traded by jp7161 or dsgolovin, thanks Joseph and David! Clear bright golden with a small white head and good lacing. Aroma of brettanomyces, wood, lemon, white grapes and slight barnyard notes. Taste is moderate to high sour, white grapes, lemon and wood. Mouthfeel is aggressive and leaves the palate dry. Very complex and wild beer, I really liked it!

Poured a cloudy yellow straw colour.  Carbonation was initially high but became lifeless rather quickly. The aroma is big fruit and sour. Think lemon. The flavour is sour and fruity. The sourness hangs on the palate forever. A nice beer to taste but that's where it ends.

Bottle shared.  Pours cloudy straw with a ring off white head.  Aroma of horse blanket, barnyard funk, grapes and tarte fruit.  Flavour is fairly heavy sour.  Medium bodied with soft but prickly carbonation.  A nice sour, but overrated in my opinion.

sample courtesy of a friend.
Thin white head.  Sour aroma.  Hazy blond pour.  Sour taste.  Not really my cup of tea.
Bottle.  Woody vinegar and sour grape aroma.  Golden yellow with moderate but short lasting head.  Very sour/tart vinegar and musty lemon flavor.  Like Im back in Brussels.

Bottle. Golden with a moderate white head. Funky, fruity, lactic, woody, vanilla aroma. Tart fruity, funky brett, spicy woody, and light vanilla flavor. Medium body, moderate acidic burn, lively carbonation.

Bottle. White head, clear golden color. Geuze-like aroma (brett, horse-blanket, grain), but very fruity, flowers and some kind of candy (dutch: tumtum, marsepein). Sour in taste, green apples and a hint of lemon. A sharp sour lingers on for a while. Im not a sour addict, but this one was pleasant. Not sure wether is batch 002 +, but is says 6 % alc.

375ml bottle thanks to wavers1 
Appearance: Cloudy golden with a medium sized white head, light lacing 
Aroma: Tart fruit, brett and citrus 
Taste: Tart fruit, woody, citrus with a dry finish 
Very good and easy drinking.
Tart aroma. Strong lemon-like sour citrus flavor. Some "wild" spicy flavor. Really nice - Thanks, Craig...

Bottle at home - 11/11/12 thanks to Frank (Ramnuts). Batch #5.
Lightly hazed pale golden witha small bubbly off white head on pour that soon vanishes without trace. Small bubbles rise from bottom to top.
Nose comprises woody tones, sour apples, burnt sugars, light vinegar notes, caramelised pears, browned apple skin, crisp and tarte.
Tastes of lemon, bitter stewed pears, apple tones, bitter grapefruit, touch of bretts but not huge, wood, tarte, sour, light vinegar but well balanced.
Medium bodied with spritzy carbonation leading to a slightly burnt tarte finish.
Excellent.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Rating # 100

Batch 3 shared by me.  

wowww, popped this open and out came the funk... very cheesy but in a great way.  taste was extremely sour, especially towards the end of the bottle.  Lemon/ Orange peel, citric acid,  suttle yeast, extremely funky.  As the beer came to temperature the flavors really blended well together and started to ripen.  The cheesy funk remained while the beer continued to get more and more sour.  I can only imagine what batch PH1 and 2 taste like...

19th October 2012THE Sour and Saison tasting. Batch 5 - thanks Bruce. Light haze on this gold beer, little white head. Crisp palate - dry. Fairly sharp lemony sourness. A little seltzer minerals. Sharp orange peel. White wine vinegar in the semi dry finish. Okay but could not drink much of it.

Batch 5. Clear golden with a thin white head that fades fairly quickly. Love the aroma - great combination of acidity/vinegar, funk, bit of barnyard, lemon zest, tart grapefruit. Mild carbonation and full acidic and vinegar body without much balance (puckering sour), become somewhat dry, so sour on the finish I almost get a bit of a sweetness. I guess I prefer my sours more like the aroma on this versus the incredibly vinegar palate that I get - not sure if it needs some more age of its just brewed this way but glad I got to try this.

Bottle @ THE Sour and Saison Tasting. Batch #5. Cheers Deeblo! The pours a medium golden amber color with a tiny white head. The nose is light lemon peel and soft wood, some fruity sugars and light cheesy funk. The taste is funky fermenting apple skin, some sweet caramel and toffee. Theres a delicate acetic funk, notes of molding pear and grape. The beer grows more strongly acidic through the taste, with some citrus fruit coming through on the finish. Mild pillowy lactic flavors provide some depth. Medium body, smooth and quite drinkable, if tart. Overall, a very nice American sour. Pretty good.

Bottle (batch #5) thanks to deeblo, at THE sour tasting (part 1). It pours cloudy golden yellow, with an orangish hue and a thin white head. The nose is soft, orange, tangerine, sherbet, light creaminess, coconut and almond. The taste is tart lemon, kumquat, sour orange,grapefruit, grape skin, sherbet, spritzy, some barnyard, subtle spice and sour sweets (warheads) and some acidic burn, with a very tart finish. Medium body, moderate acidity and prickly carbonation. Not massively complex , but pretty tasty stuff indeed.

C&C bottle served in a Deschutes tulip. Batch 5. Huge thanks again to Andrew (nasty31).

A: Pours with a light golden haze and frothy, airy white head. It recedes to a similar ring that leaves some splotches here and there.

S: Tartness and mild sourness. A mix of fresh tart fruit, mainly green apple and lemon grass with restrained funk.

T: Gueuze-ish with a slight restrained funk. Tart green apples, lemon grass, mild funk and some oak with a finish of vanilla sweetness that mixes with a little white grape sournes.

M: Zesty and spritzy. The body is light with a refreshing clean finish.

O: Delicious beer that borders on a gueuze IMO. If the funk wasnt so restrained in the backbround Id say this wasnt a wild ale, but very good none the less.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2012

Batch 5  375 ML
Thanks to Owen for the bottle

Clear golden straw color. Bright white head that fades away quickly. No lacing. 
Lemon zest, grapefruit, pear, apple, oak, vinegar, and straw. Big, badass nose. 
Lots of citrus and pear in the taste. Big amounts of sourness that came right at me. Impressive taste. 
Sour feel and a dry finish. Very solid and very challenging to my palate. Top notch stuff

Poured into a tulip. Batch #5, bottled on 01/10/12.

3.0 A: Very faintly hazed concentrated urine color. Two and a half fingers of frothy white head. Retention is average at best and no lacing is left.

4.0 S: Pears, pears, and more pears. This is the peariest beer Ive ever smelled. Hay is the next most aggressive note. Moderately tart with more of the wild qualities being of the funk variety. Musty basement, dry-rotten sweatsocks, rotting wood, and dusty old barn. Lemon, vanilla, and oak to round this off. Its complex, but the aromas dont run very deep, if that makes any sense. 

4.5 T: Pears dominate the taste as well and it tastes great. Much more tart and acetic than the nose. Plenty of lemon and tart white grape with some lime underneath. The funk mentioned in the nose follows. The taste is both complex and deep. Its potent, yet quite refined. After having a bunch of Bruery sours lately, the quality of this one is that much more apparent. Although this is good and tart, its still nicely balanced.

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Higher, but normal range, carbonation with a dry champagne-like spritziness as opposed to a sweet creaminess. Good here.

5.0 D: A couple categories were borderline with a higher score, so hence a 5.0 here. This is the first RR sour that has truly impressed me since I first had Tempation. Solid all around.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-07-2012 23:44:33

Pours a yellow hazy, straw color with a white head that fizzes away quickly. Aroma is funky, horseblanket, barnyard, citrus, lemon, hay, green apple tartness, a white wineous note in there, musty old cellar, earthy. Taste is very sour, green apple tartness, funky, refreshing, wet hay, musty. Really complex in both aroma and taste. This is a very good sour ale from RR!

Edit: As it warms up a bit I also get a nice oaknote both in aroma and taste just adding another layer of complexity to this awesome brew!

375mL bottle, sent from javit (thanks a lot, Adam), pours a cloudy golden blond with a medium white head. Nose is intensely funky and moderately acidic, with lots of the oak barrels showing off, lots of bretty funk, and some lambic-like tartness. Flavour is massively tart, probably more tart than any sour Ive had, with loads of tart rotting fruits (somehow, in a good way), loads of bretty funk, and a moderate oak barrel presence. I wouldve thought such extreme tartness would make it undrinkable, but coupled with the oak barrels and the brett funk, the complexity is very high and the drinkability is quite high for a sour. Its got a lot in common with a lambic. Excellent stuff.

Bottle of Batch 4 Jenny and I split to celebrate our moving into our new home in Ottawa. Pours a thick, mazy, matte gold with creamy white head. Complex, rich citrus aroma. Full bitter lemon rind and grapefruit aroma complemented by soft grass, oak, and strawberry notes. The flavor, wow, is basically perfect. Rich and complex, yet light and balanced. Insanely drinkable. Beautiful lemon rind, oak, and slight soap at the beginning before a juicy rush of delicious grapefruit. Slight lactic acid bite with funk and plenty of lingering grapefruit. Its delightfully tangy, moderate acidity, mild funk, with mild lemon rind notes. Theres a gentle fade of the grapefruit, and the tang makes it lip-smacking good. I dont say this lightly: this is probably the best beer Ive ever had. To be so rich with everything I want in a sour ale and yet light enough to remain insanely drinkable and never overwhelming... this is just remarkable. I hope I have the pleasure of having it again, and if it meets expectations, I may have to bump this up to a perfect 5.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 Bottle 37,5 cl tnx to Greg. Pours cloudy golden amber with a nice  diminishing off white head leaving laces. Aroma is sweet sour acidy fruity honey stable fudge apricots. Flavor is sour acidy acetone tart fruity in front, all that sustained with some bitterness adding on in the middle together with some more fruityness and astringent touch. Finishes tart sour and a bit pungent peppery.

375ml cork n cage. Pours dark golden with no lasting head to speak of. Little ring of lace. Much funk on the nose with a real Sauvignon blanc sort of grassy acidic note. A dry yeasty note as well. Awesomely lemony sour on the palate. Quickly followed by a sharp oak and funk kick. Finishes sour again. Greatness.
UPDATED: SEP 19, 2012 Bottle from beer boxer has extreme tartness great sour. Color is yellow with an off white head.
batch 5. Funk aroma, citrus & lemon, astringent, dry, white wine and grape skins, tannic & woody, sweet lemon zest finish, tart & sour
At the far extreme of tartness, slightly sour, and completely dry. Very refreshing with some tropical fruit and a little farmhouse funk. One of my favorites.

Batch #3 and #5, courtesy of Dak. Pours a bright yellow w/ a bubbly white head. Wow! Huge nose & flavors of funk, sour, lemon, barnyard. The sourest beer Ive ever had, by far! Batch #5 was even more intense than #3. A fun beer!

Pours a hazy golden color with nice white head.  Aroma is tropical fruits, lemon, and funk.  Taste is crazy tart and a bit fruity like apricot and grapefruit.  Very good albeit a bit more tart then I liked.

wow, big thanks to tooch for this one. WOW this is the tartest sourest beer ive ever had. Dont get me wrong I love tart but I feel that it takes away a little from the other stuff in beer. You can pick out some of the barrel aging in there as well.

Pors a hazy honey color with a thin ring of white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma has funky barnyard notes, some tartness, grapefruit, mild leather and cheese.  Flavor is very funky with leathery notes, some tart lemon, and lots of wonderful grapefruity bitterness.  Mouthfeel is light and lively with a funky/lightly bitter finish.  wow!

Bottle shared by alexsdad06, thanks Brad. Poured a clear golden color with an average frothy off-white head with good lacing. Moderate to heavy sour, yeast and tart aroma. Medium to full body and a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy complex sour & sweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet & sour finish of moderate to long duration. This is a complex standout beer.

The end part of a 375ml bottle, thanks to alexsdad06. Bottled 1/10/12 (Im assuming this is batch 002 +). Cloudy peach color, with all the thick stuff in the end of the bottle. Minimal small white ring of head. Awesome great tart strong sour taste. Very light carbonation, super dry finish. Great long tart aftertaste. Lemony, citric aroma somewhere beneath the big tart taste. I dont think Id want a whole bottle of this to myself, but this is a great one to share.

Bottle, batch 4, shared at Wood Shop 7, 2012. Cloudy salmon-orange color, funky citrus nose, acidic. Flavor is big citrus: grapefruit and lemon, nice funk. More citrus coming through than lambic-like funk. Very nice.

We decided to do a segmented vertical at ffej of july this year. I brought my Batch #2, Deuane brought his Batch #3, and Jwiss22 brought his Batch #5. This review will be from my Batch #2 bottle.

A - Pours hazy golden yellow with a small half finger tall white head leaving very small streaks of lace down a small portion of the glass.

S - Smells of lots of acidic sourness, white grape, lemons, green apples, oak and some barnyard funk. Batch #2 is mostly sourness at this point, Batch #3 has all the flavors in near perfect balance and  Batch #5 is probably the "fruitiest" of the three.

T - Starts off with an intense sourness that never really goes away. The fruit - the lemons, grapes and apples from the nose - combine with some musty barnyard funk and dry oak to offer some contrast  to the sourness but they can only do so much. Finish is quite dry, lingering on the palate long after consumption.

M - All three batches possess a light body with intense flavors and moderate to moderately low carbonation. Very sour, dry finish on all three batches.

O - All three of these were really awesome. My Batch #2 was definitely the most sour, Batch #3 was probably my favorite since it was the most balanced and Batch #5 just tasted a little raw compared to the other two. This was a seriously delicious test.

1800th rating. Bottle. Pours a cloudy yellow orange with small off white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is Funk and grapefruit. Thin mouthfeel with a Strong tart flavor and sour finish. Easy to drink, refreshing. A very impressive sour ale from Russian River.
Bottle shared by Anacrime @ Sour & Bitter, Thanks buddy. Hazy yellow with a small head. Aroma is earthy, pear, citrus, wood, grapes. Flavor is earthy, citrus, wood, grapes. Medium carbonation.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2012 What a massive beer! Pours an impressive orangeade syrup tone portraying an off-white that stays around for quite awhile and its lace? Fucking unbelievable. Think spiderwebs and morning eye gunk. The smells are eruptive: funked yeasts, ginger, pinewood chips, chives and melon.  Tastes of sour blended beer done right and done with interesting additions. I get funk, cornstarch, grapefruit zest (amazingly big in this sour), pine needles, salt water and licorice (slight, but its there). Has a sort of lingering alcohol presence that doesnt overwhelm nor exacerbate the flavors. A real winner in the Sour Ale category.

Poured from a 375ml corked and caged bottle into a Spiegelau tulip. Bottled on 1/10/12 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours a light honey gold with a 1-2 finger sudsy snow white head. There is a fair amount of sludgy buildup inside the bottle where the cork came out, but it doesnt seem to pour into the beer. The head dissipates quickly leaving a small ring around the edges before finally disappearing altogether. Little to no lacing once the head dissipates.

Smell: Tart, but not overpoweringly. There is a hint of barnyard funk to go along with apple cider, sweet white wine, lemon, vinegar and a touch of oak. Extremely complex aroma which balances sweetness with tartness.

Taste: Wow, thats one intensely tart array of flavors! Vinegar and wine grape hulls up front followed by sweet cider and touch of funk in the middle before ending with lemon zest and just a faint hint of oak. Aftertaste is bitter, tart and very dry with notes of earthiness, oak tannins and a little funk.

Mouthfeel: Light-to-medium-bodied with an very high amount of prickly carbonation. The mouth is coated by the puckering sourness.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. I could drink a lot of this beer if only I were lucky enough to have multiple bottles.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. Russian River really knocked it out of the park with this one. I cant imagine a sour beer getting much better than this. I cant recommend it enough.

I shared this at my tasting on August 7, 2010. Served alongside six other Russian River wild ales.

Batch 003

A: Beatification appears a very hazy yellow hue. There is a small head comprised of white bubbles that leaves a little lacing on the glass.

S: The aroma is simply amazing. I was expecting great things, and was not disappointed. Sour funk, lemons, hay, and brettanomyces are the basic makeup of the scents.

T: Not surprisingly, Beatification tastes phenomenal, as the fine aroma would indicate. Really tart, this is almost like a lemon gueuze. The aroma is staggering as you get the glass near your face, then the flavor is just awesome. The taste was an instant 5. World class.

M: As sour as this beer is, there is no harshness or astringent aspects to it. A pleasant pucker and lingering aftertaste with every drink.

D: I would drink this every day if it were feasible. Wow.

375ml bottle from Dak and Rayl101!  Pours a clear golden color with a thin white head.  Active carbonation.  Aroma has lots of citrus, funk, mustiness.  Taste is sweet with lots of puckering tartness.  Its not overpowering tart/sour as the sweetness reels it back in.  Very good stuff.

Batch 005 w Andy James Max. Straight shiny gold pour w almost no head. Smells of modest white wine, undertones of sour grapes. Very sour palate: white wine, vinegar, etc. Very sweet and tasty. Awersome sour.

375ml bottle (batch 2, notes from 12/31/10).  Pours a hazy golden color with a small soapy white head.  The aroma is barnyard and funky, very tart citrus, big lambic character, some cheese notes.  The flavors showed much of the same; funk, dank, citrus, tart, and dry.  This is sour and yet refreshing at the same time. Good carbonation helped to make this pop.  I have found that with beers like this I have trouble finding the right words to describe how much I enjoy the beer.  I thought that although this was definitely sour, it still had great drinkability and was one of my favorite beers in 2010.

Bottle shared at home with my wife. Poured a beautiful glowing, golden color with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Aroma is very gueuze-like, with smells of peaches, pears, funk, must, citrus, and a touch of vanilla. Taste is very, very sour, so sour it will melt your face, but it is awesome. Flavors of sour apricots, funk, horse blanket, wax, vinegar, and citric acid, but really just sour through and through. Mouthfeel is light with fizzy carbonation. An extremely, delicious and overwhelming sour, but not for the faint of heart. Leaves my mouth feeling raw and tingly. Another great RR beer!
Bottle to taster (thanks alexsdad06). Looks good; yellow and hazy. Smells great! Like a great geuze. Tastes good. Funky and geuzy. Good on the palate too. YES!!!

June 29, 2012 bottle shared by Brandon. Yellow hazy pour with some head that faded quickly.  Citrus and funk in the aroma.  Taste was consistent with aroma with a woody finish.  Kind of like sucking on a lemon warhead, but that is not a bad thing.  Thanks for sharing Brandon, amazing beer!  Bottled 01.10.12.

Sour is not my style at all, scent is woody and lemon notes. Taste is a lemon warhead from back in school.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to bugdoc for this one. 12 vintage poured from bottle to over-sized Mikkeller wine glass:

Pours a beautiful orange/honey gold with carbonation clinging to every corner of the glass. A lively two fingers of starch white head doesnt last as long as Id expect. Could be the glass though. Still perfect lacing though.

The nose is intense, complex. Obvious funky honey and lemongrass. A deeper kind of sour, not as bright as its brothers and sisters. A great smelling beer.

Wow. Massive on the tongue. Pushing a Warhead level of sour punch. The sour intensity mellows considerably as the beer warms. Grapefruit, rich esters, orange peel/orange juice, syrupy lemonade, truly a gigantic beer. Im blown away by how much flavor is crammed in here.

The sour side of the beer keeps drinkability rather low but its silky smooth mouthfeel is redeeming.

Overall, very glad to have had the opportunity to try this one. Sour beers are quite foreign to me and gems like these make me excited to try more.

Bottle. Fantastic funky, brett-y sour. Slight hazy yellow with thin head. Peach, apricot, quick puckering sour. Green apple. Big, fast, spicy. "warheads" candy, sweet, dry finish. quince. Awesome, intense, amongst the best sours Ive been able to try.

Batch 5, courtesy of a business trip to the Bay Area. Sampled on 6-6, reviewed from notes.

A: Lemon rind yellow. 1/4" head and plenty of carbonation bubbles. Looks ripe. 

N: Soured oak staves. Some acetone and barnyard funk. Lemon/sour citrus. There is an unpleasant scent wavering through this which knocks off some points. 

T: Probably a 9/10 on the sour scale. Plenty of lemon citrus, and plenty of lactic acid. Great wood base to round things out. SOme pine/earthiness, but not in the way youd get from hops. 

M: Light and spritzy

O: This is really brilliant stuff, particularly if youre in the mood for a palate scraping sour. Highly recommended, and I think RR has finally caught up to Belgium. Depends on if youre in the mood for a rounded sour or a bracing one.

batch 3 (750ml). pours a slight hazy yellow with a faint burnt orange. fizzy white head quickly dissipates leaving a light film over the top. lemon and oak up front. light vinegar and white grape. nice sourness through out. quite sour all the way through. starts off with a bit if sweetness and quickly becomes sour. mostly bitter lemon with a hint of lime. very citrus forward. a hint of funk and dry oak. very deep in flavor. carbonation is quite mild but works out well. starts out rather flat and with a swirl quickly comes to life. lots of dry oak in the finish. this is hands down the best american wild ale that resembles the belgian gueuze. amazing flavor and complexity. other sour brewers, take note. Reviewed on: 02-12-2011

375ml. bottle (batch #5), shared by Dak, (many thanks). Pours a hazy golden/yellow, with medium white head. Aroma is amazing, citrus interlaced with funky brett. Lemon, grapefruit and some yeast. Taste is sour/citrus, with big lemon and grapefruit notes and some oak lingering in the background. Finish is sharp, clean, quite refreshing, and somewhat bitter.  This ale completely hit the spot on a hot Phoenix afternoon. The best Russian River Ive tasted to date!

Pours golden color with white fizzy head.  Aroma...well, I did not care for it.  We have a dog.  Weve had 3 of them.  I know what dog chit smells like, and well...thats what I smelled in this beer.  So shocking to me, but thats what I got.  Taste is sour and really wonderful.  Sourness is not overpowering, but blends well with the light sweetness and the funk from the Brett.  Dry finish and a bubbly palate make this one nice beer.  Overall,  the flavor, tartness, and citrus notes make this a really good beer.  I just had to hold me nose to drink it.  Weird.

Bottle, thanks to matsciguy.  Thanks a TON Levi!  What a treat this beer was.  Pour is a slightly hazy golden straw with a diminishing white head that fades quickly to little/no lacing.  Aroma is nice light acid, floral brett funk, lemon, citrus rind.  Some wet wheat malt lingering in there as well.  Taste is more lemon rind, lots of lactic acid, some subdued acetic (only when warmed up), and again, lots of floral brett funk.  Light oaky tannins throughout.  Mouthfeel is prickly carbonation, light, refreshing. Quite geuze-ish in quality.  Far and away the best american made sour I have had, only lacking some in of the complex brett funk found in some of the sought after imports.  What an absolute treat.  Thanks again Levi!

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 375 ml bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. Batch 002. Pours hazy bright pale golden (yellow) with a small bubbly white head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace. Smell is sour with gooseberries, unripe currants, grass, barnyard, crackers, dry soil, lemon juice, leather, dried apricots, cape gooseberries, wild strawberries, wood, green grapes, rhubarb, dried basil and hints of blue cheese, oxidation and horse blanket.  Taste is very sour with lemon juice, grapefruit juice, hay, gooseberries, red currants, minerals, barnyard, very unripe peaches, raspberries, unripe wild strawberries, cloudberries, green apples and hints of cape gooseberries and dry soil, horse blanket, leather, rhubarb and hints of cape gooseberries. Mouthfeel is very dry, very tart and medium bodied. Finish is sour and tart with grapefruit juice, lemon zest, red currants, gooseberries, hay, dry soil, barnyard and hints of apple cider vinegar. Simply amazing! Havent tried a fresh bottle but considering this bottle Id very much recommend aging.

A - Pours a hazy golden-yellow color with a finger of frothy white head atop. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is full of barnyard funk with sour peach and pear and other light fruits. There is also some lemon peel and other citrus flavors with some oak.

T - Starts off with lots of sourness and funk with some pear and other tart light fruits and lots of farmhouse flavors. Through the middle, some more funky flavors comes through with some Brett and other wild yeast flavors and some oak. The finish is a mix of funky wild yeast flavors with lots of farmhouse flavors, strong sourness, oak, and some lemon peel.

M - Medium bodied with moderate-plus carbonation. Feels smooth with a sour and funky finish.

D - Very drinkable. The sourness and funky flavors are so strong, but at the same time the beer feels very balanced. I really like the wild yeast flavors.
Clear gold with no head.  Sourness in the nose with fruit, yeast, and vinegar.  Spicy.  This is really nice.  Quite drinkable from a guy who does not like dours.

Batch PH3 (I think). This is the fourth sour from RR Ive had (Temptation, Supplication, Consecration) and this was by far my favorite.

Beer is yellow and clear. Carbonation is moderate to low and forms a two fingered head of medium and small white bubbles. Head falls away leaving a lot of lacing behind.

Beer is a sour bomb. Totally citric and acetic but does not devolve into vinegar as some of these lighter bodied ones do. Its medium to low in body, the carbonation is important in the mouth. Drinkability is the really high and its the best tasting sour Ive had. Tartness really hits me in the corners of my mouth but overall a great and solid sour. Im shocked its not rated higher. Ill be seeking this out again.

Batch 5 bottle, pours a light hazy peach thats is almost see-through. Wonderful aroma of sour Brett and apricot. Slow, soft start with a perfectly tart middle and a lovely lingering finish without being overly sour. Light body. Probably the best Russian River beer Ive had.
Sample at Sour & Bitter, thanks to the great americans at our table. Amazing acidity, longlasting taste and palate, lots of fruit. Amazing!

Bottle shared at Berliner Bash from jredmond, thanks again for the share.  Poured a light yellow color with aromas of light sour barnyard funk with some tart lemons and yeast.  Flavors are tart fruit, and some funky citrus mixed with some light hay.  Great beer overall, glad I got to try this one out.

Bottle from Richard, thanks!  Pours out a yellow color with a white head on it.  Smell is fruity, sour, full of lemon and yeasty notes.  Taste is smooth, sour, and pretty refreshing.  I served it refrigerator cold, and it was amazing.  A really good beer, I had the batch 1 way too long ago to make any comparison.  I remember it was really good; and so was this.  Not surprising though.

Bottle. Batch 2. Pours yellow gold with white head. Nose of old wood, aged cheese, funk, lemon rind and wild yeast. Taste is mostly funky citrus, wild yeast, old dry wood and tart lemon. Finishes with tart lemon and dry wood. Well balanced not over powering tartness. Medium body.

Bottle or b5. Pours a golden to dark yellow with white head. Aroma is more funk than Ive had in any other sour RR beer. Still notes of lemon rind and some other citrus notes worked in.  Taste is tones of sour bite, some funky cheese elements and very dry compared to other RR sours.  All of this is based on the usual four, Supplication, Temptation, Consecration and Sanctification.  This is by far the best of those four from my experience, followed by Temptation. Overall, love this beer and glad I got the generous pour of the 375ml bottle that I had traded for.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: 375ml bottle, batch 5, received in trade from KevSal. Thanks! Pours a hazy, golden color with a white head. Aroma is fruity, citrus, lemon, funky, yeasty. Medium on the palate with lively carbonation. Flavor is sour, lemon, bread, Grapefruit, a little oaky, with a sour, citrusy finish. Excellent. Lives up to the hype, and on par with whats coming out of Belgium.

Batch 5 bottle pops when opened and releases a funky smell.  It pours light golden with a slight white head that quickly disappears  Aromas are citrus, hay, and funk.  Tastes are tart fruit with lemon and grapefruit noted.  Palate is medium bodied with an abrupt and tart finish.  Quite acidic, like a lemon, but with lots of great Brett funk.  Very refreshing, very delicious.  Overall, one of the best beers I have had from RR, and I have had several.  Very well done.

Batch 5 - bottle from Brandon.  Thanks!  Hazy golden and glowing pour with a solid froth of white foam that fades out to a slick.  Aroma is lemon, dry oak, sour, slight tart, and a definite cheese funk over a grainy malt presence and brett.  I do not get grapefruit but the sharp lemon and tart certainly suggests a sour citrus note.  Taste is tart, puckering, sour, grape rinds, cheese funk, lemon, and sharp tart reverberations through the finish.  The brett provides a nice dry backdrop but it does not get in the way of the other flavor components.  Mouthfeel is sharp and while not quite bone dry it has a clean presentation that showcases the tart/sour and funk very well.  Good god damn (!!) this is one exceptional sour that presents with a-grade lambic-gueuze characteristics.  Stellar and well worth seeking out.

Aroma: lots of lemon, touch of pineapple, hay, bretty funk, light sour apple character, oak.  Pours a slightly hazy straw/yellow color, white head dissipates quickly and leaves no lacing.  Poured cold, the sourness is fairly subdued, but starts to kick in as the beer warms.  Nice lactic acid character, lots of lemon, some pineapple and sour apple, sourness is moderately high but not puckering.  Nice brett character, slight sweaty/funky note, light malts and pleasant oak notes.  Light-medium body, high carbonation, effervescent.  Very complex and delicious brew - its hard to go wrong with RR sours.

375ml batch 002 poured into mini chalice. 

A - Pours a hazy golden color with a very slight fizzy white head which quickly vanishes. No head retention or lacing left behind. Not a whole lot to look at, really. 

S - Fruity tart/sour notes up front. Sour apple quicky comes to mind. This has a medium funk compared to the other RR wilds Ive had, which is nice for a change. 

T - Sour apples, medium funk, tart citrus finish. 

M - Very light with minimal carbonation. Not as dry of a finish as I was expecting.

D - Not my favorite wild from RR, but damn good anyway.

Batch 5. Minimal head. Gold color, orangish. The aroma is strong, funk, and the funk lasts in the palate. The palate seems to stick to the roof of my mouth. Tart upfront, wet wood. Fantastic sour and one I have wanted to have. A good way to enjoy my birthday! My first batch, cannot yet say how it compares to any others.

Bottle batch 002.  Aroma has notes of sour tart funk, lemon and citrus along with barnyard and flowers.  Medium yellow orange hue with no head.  Flavor is medium sweet and heavy tart.  Palate is medium bodied and watery flat.  Overall a disappointment as the beer had no carbonation what so ever.  Aroma and flavor are above average and the beer is very drinkable.

Bottle poured into glass. Oh how I love sours. This beer alone just re-affirms this. The beer is full of sour tart funk with slight dirty diaper. Slight sour burn on the way down but oh how good it feels. Loved it!!

Batch 005.  Cloudy orangish-yellow pour, smells tart and funky (good funky)..lemon, wood, and grapefruit favors....just a wonderful sour..so glad to be able to try this beer..also had a Batch 002...which while similar had its own intresting flavors.

batch 5 through a trade. pours a golden color and releases a dense head that holds up well. smell is vinegar, acetone, funk, tropical fruits light malt. taste begins with a vinegar pucker, lots of funk and acetone. some tropical fruit and light malt. the sourness feels/ tastes like vinegar. as I let the beer sit the acetone clears away leaving a much cleaner beer overall. Unfortunately I didnt enjoy this...

cool golden hue, quickly dissipating pure white head. obviously bretty and very citric. grapefruit yes but also strong tangelo, neroli. spritzy feel, lots of CO2. slightly creamy feel. very dry. acidity seems a bit buffered but this is more than moderately sour, I got a wee bit of a pucker going. Hay, other barn aromas emerging as it warms, sharp citric flavors, acidic, strong effervescence. Fantastic. I remembered Batch #1 as a jewel in a very large tasting and thought it would be tough to come close. This very much does. Im quite happy. I like everything about this.

Had a friend in Santa Rosa send me 6 of these for $30 a bottle (2x markup but Im alright with it). Poured at Cellar temp into a Duvel Tulip. Batch 5.

A - Half-Finger head. Lacing is solid but dissipated to a very thin ring of carbonation almost instantly. Dark golden color, nice haziness, looks like a standard farmhouse style saison. 

S -  Apricot sour tartness. Very wild and very hot on the nose. Intense spiciness as well thats typical with a Saison but hard to pinpoint what spices exactly.

T - Very sweet. Extremely tart. Lots of wild fruits like apricot, grapes and persimmons. Its hard to really give this rating a fair one since Ive had 5 Russian River beers tonight all sours and corked so Ill probably re-rate it. Very sweet and tart but hard to pinpoint any exact flavor.

M - 50/50 carbonation. Ultra dry finish, lingering sour taste. 

O - Fantastic. This is a great beer but Im finding it hard to really pinpoint. solid A.

Batch 005. Bottle thanks to amtran87 at Toronado. Pours a cloudy orange color with a large white head. A rich nose of wood and sour tart fruit, hay and light vanilla. The flavor is very interesting; woody, hay, rich tart sourness, at times very sour, seems like Pils malts, lingering sour wood. Complicated but very smooth and tasty. Lots of brett and layers of sourness. Very nice palate with loads of complexity.

Batch 3, thanks to JerZ
Appearance:  Pours a cloudy gold with a tight white ring.

Aroma: Diaper, big brett-like funk, pineapple.

Taste: Super tart, lemon pulp, malt presence is overpowered by tartness and funk, earthy.

Mouthfeel: Puckering. Full bodied , a slight yeasty texture.

Overall: A big thanks to my bud Jer. I had never tried this beer, and he happily busted it out for me to try.  I plan on getting more familiar with this beer when I get my hands on Batch 5.

Pours a hazy golden color with a very slight fizzy white head which quickly vanishes. Fruity tart/sour notes up front. Sour apple quicky comes to mind. Sour apples, medium funk, tart citrus finish. Very light with minimal carbonation.

From notes.  First reviewed 10/30/2011.  Poured from a 750 mL bottle into a tulip. Batch 3. Thanks to readbaron and Dunt for bringing this to our WaLe tasting.

Beatification pours a dark, cloudy golden tangerine color with a small eggshell collar and no real lacing.

The aroma has some lactic and soft funky notes, but it is mostly sour. Lemon, peach, and grapefruit all provide the fruit tartness.

The flavor has an incredible sour flavor. It starts with lemon and grapefruit, with some peach, white grape, and a bit of cherry later on. Some grass and hay get lost with the light malt; if I really look for it I can get a little bit, but the tartness is overwhelming.

The carbonation and body are standard for the style, with an absolutely incredible tartness. Some light oak tannins dry it out a bit, but the sour is so deep and full that my mouth is constantly watering while I work through my glass. 

This is one of the most puckering and blistering sour wilds I have had - I absolutely love it. It reminds me of an incredibly tart gueuze.

Batch 2 with James and pat. Pours a nice hazy gold with some slight head. Aroma is funky and slighty dank. Taste is wonderful, really nice balance between tart sourness and quenching. Some amazing aged cheese flavors come through to complete it. A really fantastic ale. Thank you James.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2013 from city beer A - pours hazy vibrant golden yellow with high off white head. Bubbles lace the glass. S - Chardonnay wine and barnyard funk. Hints of lemon peel, grapefruit, and salt. M - very sour beer light body with high carb. T - sour acids, lemon and lime on the nose. Nice Chardonnay and sour apples on the palate, hints of grapes and funky yeast. Nice funk on the end. O - great sour beer. Easily my favorite sour/wild. Another fantastic showing from RR 8+

Sour barnyard and hay smell. Cloudy yellow with little to no head. Tart up front and white wine. Finishes very sour with grapes and grapefruit. Great beer. Drank at tion night at toronado during beer week, Natalie brought two huge bottles, said they were three years old.

Gift from Sj. WHat I loved about this one was the earth, tart, fruit and citrus flavors. 

However, there is so much more complexities going on in this beer, I cant figure it all, but with that said, it is amazingly blended well.
bottle shared by Marcus.pours gold with a small white head. Aroma is spoiled wine. Flavor is very sour like a war head that finishes bitter.

Batch 2 375 bottle. Pours flat with no carbonation. Hazy yellow. Huge nose full of citrus and Brett. Taste is sharp and tangy, with a very lemony/citrus flavor.  The brett is subdued. Teeth numbing tartness. Still very nice after all these years.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
UPDATED: APR 9, 2012 Batch #005......Aroma is very funky, it has agrapefruit notes but a bit less lemon in the nose than the last batch. Appearance is a yellow color with a bit of orange when held up to a light. Taste is very satisfying. Very similar to what I remembered in batch #004. It has notes of white pepper and citrus that go together beautifully. This is an amazing beer. Easily my favorite sour/wild ale from Russian River. Refreshing is a good way to describe this beer.

Batch #004........Aroma is full of funk, it also carries a certain lemon rind or citrus in the nose. The appearance is a crystal clear golden color with bubbles streaming off the bottom of the glass. The taste is very nice. The sour notes come through very crisp and clean with some grapefruit flavors coming through. It is a very drinkable beer and it definitely doesnt lack flavor.

Bottle, batch 002.  Clear piss yellow pour with a hint of white head.  Enticing lemon zest and funk aromas.  Tart, crisp, and clean with all kinds of lemon zest, sour vinous & grapefruit, barnyard, and funk notes.  Absolutely freakin delicious...

Tasted on 11/11/11 from a corked and caged 375mL bottle obtained in a trade from SourNotes, Batch 002.  Pours cloudy light orange with just a thin white layer of lace that quickly disappears, leaving nothing.  The nose is fresh grapefruit, sour lemon (peel and flesh), tons of earthy barnyard funk, green apple, white wine vinegar, and just a hint of a fleshy red berry aroma as well.  The flavor is sour lemon, fresh grapefruit, fleshy red berries, green apple skin, tons of earthy barnyard funk, and a vinous note.  The body is medium with sticky tannins, light carbonation, and a long, sour lemon, grapefruit peel, and bretty barnyard funk finish.

Pours hazy yellow//orange with a small white head. Aroma has lemon, lime, orange peel, apricot, lusty sourness, oak sweetness and all the fruits of a well-crafted sour ale. Lots of sour berries - supremely balanced and well-managed. Taste has tons of lemon (das autozitron!), tart, yeasty funkiness, lemon peel, some grapefruit - also extremely fruity. Plenty of sour grapes and berries - more geuze than Wild ale, really. Very nice texture, adequate carbonation.

Batch 002. Bottle looks simple but good. Beer in the glass deep golden, no head. Starts very intense sourish, salty, a bit moldy. Dry background. Fruity like lemon and grapefruit. Finish a bit milder, but still very sour. Not my favourite!
38cl, Batch 2, recently retired exclusive American brew, thx to Walt!, complex sour brew, very sour and slightly woody/fruity, yet balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, good brew

This one was sampled during the South Carolina tasting. This was courtesy of beermex2, thank you immensely Steve! 

This one pours a light to medium bodied melted butter in appearance with a light white lacing. It smells of light Granny Smith apples with some apricot and peaches. This is officially the first beer to make me pucker. Wow! This is mind blowingly sour. It is just so tart and you dont get killed with brett its really astonishing. What a sour! As far as sours go, this is a sipper, an utter palate destroyer. Phenomenal, phenomenal beer.

Bottle. 12.7 oz. Split with and courtesy of Jimmy Redman. Big thanks to James for sharing this rare beauty. Pours a shimmering golden straw with a soft, modest white pristinely bubbled head. Very minimal, spotty lacing. The nose is soft, sharp aged cheddar cheese, rustic peccorino, lemon zest, soft lavender notes, and hints of tropical fruits; pineapple, tangerine, and bitter grapefruit. The funkiness in the aroma is mouth-watering. Very tight, tart, and astringent mouthfeel on such a light, almost airy body. The sourness is overwhelming at first, but slowly fades and gives way to a plethora of tropical fruit flavors, pineapple and fresh lemons, a bit of earthiness, and tons of savory backbone to support it all. The finish is quite dry and yet complex; it reminds me a lot of a much more sour, wild Temptation with less champagne notes. This sour is truly special, a unique, exceptionally refined wild ale that epitomizes the style and yet manages to push it beyond, into uncharted territory.

Bottle split with pat for mount eerie sourfest 2011. Pours a bright orange body with nice glaze and controlled white lacing. Aroma is full of tropical fruits - peaches, apricot, grapefruit and pineapple; and also some funky cheese. Mouthfeel is crazy hypnotic tart with notes of sour peaches, aged cheese, apricot.

Bottle in California at Toronado SD. Huge thanks to Ian, the owner of Toronado for going to his private reserve cellar and cracking a bottle of his and Vinnys favorite sour batch. Aged 9 to 19 months. Pours a shimmering, glowing, bright golden color. Zero head, lacing evident in middle of beer. Aromas of funky sour aged wood, parmesan and gouda mixed, grapefruit, lemon zest, white peaches. Softest and most velvety mouth feel I have ever tried for a wild ale. Taste is barnyard horseblanket, lactic notes, white wine, fresh squeezed lemon juice, slight caramel, and a good amount of grapefruit, tropical sourness. Finishes complex with unique wood flavors and slightly puckery on the tongue. I was told this is the most sour batch of all the Beatificications. Reminded me of a 5-6 year old 3 Fonteinen or Cantillon unblended lambic gueuze. So balanced you forget there is any alcohol in it. Incredible Sour, Thanks Ian.

Bottled. Batch # 3. Thx. to Sarro for this. Golden coloured. Unclear. Small light beige head. Immense aroma of grape, sourness, ripe fruits, orange, some tart, light horseblanket, leather, wood and earth. Wow. Flavour equally complex. Loads of grape, citrus, brett, wood, apricot, sourness, barnyard, earth, leather and then some. Medium to full bodied. Ens on a tarty and grapy sourness. Greatness in a bottle.

Got the Batch 002. Pours rather clear golden/amber with a tiny white head. Aroma is citrus, lime, orange, peel, funk, oak, rural, light tartness, sour berries, and freshness. Taste is lemon, tart, lime, orange peel, pink grapefruit, sour berries, oak and ruralness. Tons of fruity impressions here which take this beer to another level.. Give me more please.

Bottle 37,5 cl, from a trade with MatSciGuy. Batch 002. Pours slightly hazy orangy yellow with a small white head. The first thing I thought when I smelled this beer was: Authentic.Funk, brett, horseblanket, orange, oak, ripe apricots and orange zest. It reminds me of Girardin Gueuze Black Label, just really pleasantly balanced between a beautiful strong fruitiness and a funky brett background. The tartness is full throttle in the taste, and the funk also comes through powerfully. There is ana amazing fruity side, lots of citrus, "Autozitron", pink grapefruit. Tastes like a Black Label Girardin with added lemon zest and grapefruit. One of the best Gueuzes Ive had this far.

003 750 thanks to Chris! Oaky cheesecloth, bubblegum, nectar, lactic acid, acetic acid, and grapes in the nose lead to an ultra sour flavor with dank brett, pure yummy acid, oak, and massive lemon. Perfect bubbly body- slippery and dry as fuck.

Batch 003, 750 mL bottle huge thanks to Chris at Ebenezers. Cloudy golden pour. Nose of subtle complex yeasty funk mixing with light herbal notes, phenomenal wood and white wine, cheesecloth, apricot and nectarine. Flavor holds an incredibly puckering sour presence with more great nectar notes and vanilla, vinous wood that comes and goes like an undulating wave on the ocean. Huge lemon presence as well. Unbelievably good.

pours a straw yellow with a thick white head. aroma is lemon, tart vinegar, acetic sour, barnyard.Flavor is sharply sour with citrus notes. like all russian river beers, just a perfect mouthfeel. overall just a great beer.

Batch #2 
Lambic-säuerlicher Antrunk, etwas hopfig. Der säuerliche Teil geht im Mittelteil in den Hintergrund, vollmundig, deutliche Spuren von Äpfeln. Zum Ende eher bitter. 	 
Test vom 14.8.2008, Gebinde: Glasflasche 	Noten: -,11,11,11,10,11 - 10,94

Batch 2 bottle opened last night.  Just a tiny pop when the bottle was opened.  Pour was clear golden orange color.  Fairly still.  Very tart aroma.  White grapes, green apples, some funk, and some lemon zest.  Taste has a sharp acidic bite to it, but it never becomes too overpowering.  White grapes, tart apples, some pineapple, lemons, and funk.  The acidity quite pleasing here, and after a while becomes stronger.  The one thing this beer could use is more carbonation.  While I think this is still an amazing beer, with just some more carbonation I would probably have given this something closer to a 4.7.

Batch 002, 375ml shared with mattyb83.  Pours a hay colored golden orange with no head after a very aggressive pour.  Some bubbles laid on top reminiscent to what urine looks like in a toilet after its sat and mellowed for a little bit. The aroma is on the more subtle side of things.  A ton of lemon zest, wet blanket, barnyard, dried grapefruit rind, and brett funk.  The level of acidity is on the higher end of the spectrum which is nice, because it counteracts the lack of carbonation and saves any sort of mouthfeel that is present.  Which by the way is DRY!  Big dry flavors of lemon juice, tart apple skin, hay, lemongrass, white grapes, and funk leads into a long tart finish.  Overall a wonderful wild.  A lot of complex flavors with a soft nose and a dry mouthfeel almost get lost completely, due to the lack of carbonation, but the high acidity saved the day.

Batch 002 375ml bottle.
Received in trade from largadeer, thanks for the opportunity.

I can smell the funk as soon as I pop the cork. Pours a crystal clear deep golden color with a good sized white head that sticks around for a while. Smells of barnyard funk, lemon, tart fruits, and leather. Smells very tart, I think Im in for a treat. The taste is mouth puckering sour and dry with lots of tart fruits especially lemon and sour orange. Hints of horse blanket and tobacco round it out. Leaves a bone dry finish in which you can feel the lactic acid burn down your throat until it splashes into your stomach. Every sip leaves your mouth watering for more. Medium low carbonation, Medium light body. Wow thats a great sour beer! Lots of acid, some funk, very little vinegar. Vinnie youve done it again.

Batch 3 opened on May 4, 2011, to celebrate the end of 1L. 

Golden yellow with nice clarity. A one-finger head recedes and the beer is perfectly still, waiting.

Huge lemon-lime acidity. White vinegar. Some mushroom funkiness, hay, and light must.

Reminds me of a nice gueuze, though with an extra dose of citric acidity. A hint of oak lasts unattended for the first second, then a nice blend of lemon-juice acidity, green apple tang, and just a tiny bit of citrus (orange?) sweetness near the finish. Boundless cat pee. Very acidic, very tart, very vinegary  if B2 is every more acidic, Ill pass. Theres a discernible though almost overwhelmed oak tannic and mushroom earthiness throughout, most noticeable as a contrast to the sweeter notes. Mostly acidic though.

Medium, medium light and surprisingly slick, if not oily, the finish lingers on and on. Lower carbonation. When life gives you lemons 

One of the best wild ales out there, at least in my experience. The gueuze comparisons are inevitable, though this is less balanced and more overtly tart and less funky than befits that style. So clean and sharp, though not without its rawness. A treat, and one of the bars for the style.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2014 750 ml bottle of Batch 003 shared by STLWill- thanks a ton, Will, for letting me try this long-time want! Tried side-by-side with Framboise for a Cure at Dark Lord Day 2011. Pours a cloudy golden-yellow color with a small white head. Aroma of lemon and grapefruit citrus, oak, straw, vanilla, yogurt, lactic acid, and caramel. Flavor of lemon citrus, bretty funk, yogurt, vanilla, brown sugar, balsamic, oak, and grapes. If my notes were better, I probably could have listed flavors in here for days. So complex. Medium-bodied, with a tart, funky mouthfeel and medium carbonation. I thought the raspberries in the FFAC gave it the slight edge but these were both mind-blowing. Re-Rate: Batches 2-6. Confirming the 4.5 Amazing.

DLD 11.  Side by side with the framboise for a cure, big thanks to STLWill for this one.  Hazy yellowish pour, with thin white head.  Aroma has notes of lemon, tart vinegar, acetic sour, barnyard, cheese, some hay and layers of oak and slight vanilla.  Taste is complex, layered, funky, sour, and delicious.  Notes of tart lemon, green apple, big horse leather, funk, cheese, some acetic slight vinegar notes but works extremely well, finishing with oak, vanilla, tannic and delicious.  Cant rave enough...
Batch 3.  Pours hazy yellow. Aroma is citrus with a lot of funk. has a light crisp body. Flavor is sour with a woody citrus flavor to it. Overall a great beer.

Bottle courtesy of northernbrews. Batch 3. Pours a hazy straw with a light lacing that coats the glass. Aromas are citrus, with huge funk.body is light, and crisp. Flavor is sharply sour with citrus notes. My comments don do this Justice. Absolutely incredible!
Bottle... Batch 2 poured a hazy goldenish with an off-white head.  Some lactic acid with tart vinegar tones.  Mild fruitiness mixed with some brett and funk tones.  Woody and a candied sweetness.

I had a batch 2 375ml bottle that i drank from Rochefort glass. 

This beer pours a dark yellow that has a hint of orange in it, much much darker than tempation. The head and carbonation are both disappointing as I get NO HEAD AT ALL. There is no lacing either.

The aroma is all sour and funk but sadly there isnt much complexity or other aromas. You are just overwhelmed by sour.

The taste makes up for what is lacking in appearance and aroma. It is sweet to start then very tart, definetly a puckerer, the rest of the way but not so overwhelming you cant drink it.

The feel is tart and heavy and just coasts your tongue but crisp to drink and great drinkability for a sour beer.

Overall this wild ale is a good beer, partly just because I love sours. however, compared to other sours it is severly lacking in complexity and originality. Would I drink this beer again? Certainly. Would I go out of my to find it, trade something special to get it, or pay a lot at an auction site no.

Shared by a friend at December tasting.  Batch 2 and 3 next to each other.

Notes from Batch 2
A-pours a bright golden yellow liquid that glows in the light with a creamy white head.

S-the nose is huge, tons of funk, lots of barnyard with notes of cheese.  there are earthy yeasts, a fair bit of sourness in the nose with light signs of acidity.  big fruits come in behind, tart lemons, sour peaches, juicy golden fruits.

T-this is very well integrated with great funk notes up front.  the earthy barnyard aromas carry right into the flavor, light flavors of cheese, hints of yeast.  juicy golden fruits are blended in with the funk with some tart lemon, light pear and peach flavors with a strong sourness to it.

M-the fel is livey and mouth puckering, medium to full body with a syrupy texture but soft and supple on the palate.  nice dry finish and still a persistent sour feel.

D-this is extremely well balanced with a great funk to it not seen in most american sours.  very gueuze like with plenty of fruit sweetness to add deep complexity and balance.

Batch 3-this is also very solid, would get a slightly lower rating.  it has the same complex funk to it that Batch 2 had.  It has slightly more acidity but still has the same assertive sourness. It also doesnt have the bright golden fruit presence that batch 2 has, it is there but not quite as vibrant.  Integrated well but slightly less complex.

Bottle, with huge thanks to oakbluff once again. Pours hazy gold, thin white head, spotty lacing. Nose is profoundly tart-smelling, with loads of sweat, acid, leather, lemon peel, brett. One of the finest aromas I have smelled on a beer to-date. Flavours are sweaty and very sour. Bone dry palate, with spice, salt, sweat, and horse. So much horse... Brilliant!

Bottle, batch 2, shared with LeopoldStoch. Pours a cloudy yellowish brown.  The head is white and thin. It had that typical horseblanket, citrus funk on the nose but there was an added level of complexity that I can only describe as a pleasant "mustiness". The flavors were the same and they were accompanied by an incredible, cheek puckering, sourness that I absolutely loved. Not that I have had a lot of Russian River offerings but this is, to date, my favorite from them.

On tap at Russian River Night at Toronado.  Batch 3.  Pours a clear amber with with a small white head that has decent retention and leaves a bunch of small spots of lacing on glass.  Aroma is very funky with big grapefruit and a mineral presence.  Also a big of oak and some champagne yeast.  Initial taste is huge tart grapefruit which goes into some lemon and mineral.  Some light oak as well.  Possibly the most sour beer I have had.  Mild astringency.  Light-medium body.  Medium carbonation.  Right up there with the best beers that Russian River (or anyone else) has to offer.

Bottle thanks to JohnGalt1. Pours golden yellow topped with a small fizzy head. Aroma was of sour grapes, light vanilla, and some citrus. Taste was very nice with more of the sour, tart green grapes, a little wood, some other fruit notes , and a little funk.

Batch 2 bottle, shared with Shaun at Hill Farmstead. A million thanks, sir.

Pours a light, golden color with a nice white head and moderate carbonation. 

Strong, aggressive aroma of brett, barnyard, must and funk. Pure, unadulterated funk, as youd want in a wild ale.

Taste is astounding, especially in contrast to its aroma. Reminds me of Sour Patch Kids candy. Tart, super sour and fruity, but surprisingly drinkable. 

Wonderful experience.
Perhaps, my favorite beer.  Heavily tart/sour, citrus, grapefruit notes.  Literally, spent 2 hours savoring it during Russian River night at SD Toronado.

750 ml Batch #2 bottle, courtesy cmillward. Thanks for cracking this open Chris! This pours a hazy, glowing golden orange color and crowned by a small off white head of foam that quickly recedes to a thin film leaving skinny rings of lace on the glass. The aroma is mouthwatering showing notes of sour lemon rinds, grapefruit, and orange followed by funky barnyard yeast, oak, and must. This smells as true to a Belgian gueuze lambic as you will find in the US. The flavor follows suit and is just as intensely sour as the nose lets on with the lemon, lime, and grapefruit dominating with the wild, musty yeast, and acetic acids coating the palate. The funky brettanomyces adds some nice dryness along with some earthy qualities. Clean oak and a hint of vanilla add beautiful balance to all the sourness. Medium bodied with perfect carbonation and nearly bone dry with a hint of sourness on the finish. This is great tasting beer that is completely refreshing. Just a fantastic beer all around.

Batch 3 750 courtesy of Weisguy, thanks!
Pours a nice golden mellow yellow with little head. Tons of brett, sour lemons & some oak in the smell. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but nicely carbonated. The incredible sourness of this beer extends itself through the tongue to the cheeks and out. Lots lemon & lime sour along with some sour patch kids.

tasting.  Batch 3.  So happy I got to try this!  cloudy yellow pour with a 1 finger white head.  tart nose with some dry musty brett / barnyard notes.  tart up front on the mouth with apple notes on the sides.  perfect level of sourness throughout with sweet grape and apple notes.  dry mouth puckering finish.  awesome!
Bottled, batch 003. Hazy blonde color, short head. Tart aroma, candy sweetness, barnyard. Hint of peppermint. Quite sour. Good stuff.

From notes:

Batch 003 750ml received as an extra in a trade with ipa247. Thanks a lot man! Your generosity knows no bounds.

Pours a dark hazy golden banana yellow color with golden yellow hues when held to a light source and a two finger frothy white head. Decent retention, slowly fading into a lasting ring that leaves sporadic spots of lacing behind.

Funky Brett aroma with hints of earthy oak, crisp light fruit, champagne yeast.

Medium bodied with a slightly puckering tart mouthfeel. Soft carbonation with some earthy oak notes as well as some puckering sour funk. The great thing about this beer is although it is sour and funky with dry bretty efervescence, it isnt acetic at all and is actually very well balanced by the citrus and light fruit notes. Hints of lemon peel as well as apple and pear. Complex and extremely complex with a nice tart finish. Each sip leaves me salivating for more. Get this beer!!

75 cl Bottle @ Caesars Palace. The aroma has, citrus, oranges, some barnyard and a hint of vanilla. Hazy, yellow-orange coloured beer with a thin, off-white head. The taste is very sour and tart, it has citrus, barnyard and a smooth malty background. Nice one.

Bottle @ caesar. Hazy light golden colour, small white head. Aroma is sour apple, barnyard and peppermint. Flavour is light malted, sour, hint of barnyard, some tartness. Initially sour, later a bit softer. Great stuff.

Shared with bmanning at a tasting on 09.26.09.

A: Bright golden with a little bit of haze and a little bit of fizzininess on the head.

S: A little bit of lemon citrusness paired with some green apple sourness. A little bit of vinegary acidicness in the nose as well, but nothing too overpowering.

T: Nothing too overpowering here, but in a good way. Some oak flavor to go along with the citrus and acidicness. A little bit of funkiness as well.

M: Pretty dry and fairly light-bodied. Very refreshing to have a very nice sour without too much alcohol content.

D: Exceedingly drinkable. This one was fantastic and hopefuly Ill get another try some day.

Entered to celebrate my 5800th Rating. Bottle @ Ulfborg Friday Night Tasting Session. Thanks to J&C. Pours clear golden with a small off white head. Nose is tart. Brett, farmhouse and horseblanket. Some lemon and wood. Tart, crisp and very dry end. Luvly!
750ml bottle shared by Madvike.  Thanks!  The aroma is very complex, soft lemony vanilla tones.  Cloudy orange-tan color.  Oily, lacy head.  Batch 3.  Soft and very authentic.  Perfect stuff.

Drank batch 2 and 3 side by side.  Batch two was much more flat in the glass and had a candied lemon thing going on and was boring compared to the 3.  The batch 3 was lively with carbonation and aroma, brightly tart grapefruit and lemon.  Bracingly tart with a fresh zippy snappy beauty in every sip.  From memory it reminds me of Girardin Black label.

375ml bottle pours a hazy gold with a thin, white head.  Nose is HUGE with brett, hay, band aid, farmyard, horsey, cheesy, herbs, spices.  Flavor is tart, lemon juice, grapefruit rind, huge tart brett, hay, spices, white pepper, rotted tropical fruits.  Full bodied, tart, acetic finish.  Really good.

375 ml. bottle and 750 ml. bottle. Thanks, Clint for the amazing side-by-side tasting of this. I believe I had batches 2 & 3 in the order relative to the sizes already mentioned. Both batches have a hazy gold appearance, but batch 3 was much more carbonated, in my opinion. Lovely sour lemon and brett aroma. The oak aging provides a distinct aroma that I have not smelled in a sour before. Both batches had a nice oaky, sour lemon, and brett bite to them. Batch 3 had the carbonation that made all of the aforementioned flavors pop. Batch 2 was relatively flat on the tongue, and didnt even compare to batch 3. Batch 3 reminded me of a Gueuze. Excellent beer, and quite distinct in comparison to other Russian River sours.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2010 Bottle. Pours a slightly haze straw color with a slight collared white head. Lemon zesty nose coupled with some barnyard. Very citrus type tart notes. Light mouhfeel with good carbonation. Slightly mouth puckering. The taste is really good with notes of oak, barnyard, lemon, grapefruit, and white grapes. Some good Brett notes without being overly floral or medicinal. Tasty, very tasty overall. Ends pretty dryly.

Batch 002 after sampling ph1:  Pours same as ph1.  Aroma is pungent, white wine vinegar, cheesy.  Flavor is peppery, cheese, white wine vinegar, some lambic-esque notes but too much off flavor.  No carbonation, medium smooth viscous, like an underattenuated lambic.  7.4.7.3.14 . . . . . .batch 003 after 002:  Pours a thinner pale yellow with a light fizzy head.  Aroma is more lambic like with a bit of pepper.  Flavor is much the same as 002 but cleaner, paper, soap, more sour, mouth puckering my notes say.  More carbonation than 002, spritzy, nice with just a touch of sweetness.  7.4.7.4.15

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2012 Bottle, 2007, at the Funky 6. Pours cloudy gold with a slight, white head. Lots of brett and tart fruits in the aroma. Flavor begins with fruity sweetness, then quickly becomes quite tart and acidic with light wood notes. Medium in body with soft carbonation. Finishes sour and lightly musty, with lingering acidity. Very nice. (4.1)Bottle (Batch #5) at THE Sour and Saison Tasting, London. Big thanks to Bruce. Pours mostly clear with a wispy, white cream head. Moderately tangy nose with hints of citrusy sugars. Light to medium sweet flavor, some spiciness, good tang with a bit of bite, light grassy bitterness. Light to medium bodied with fine to average carbonation. Decent, dirty grass hop finish with nice sourness, along with some anise qualities. A very good American sour. (4.0)
Spicy pineapple with hints candi sugar and star fruit.  Pours hazy gold with an orange hue.   Very tart upfront, tart pineapple with green apple skins, and sour white grapes.   Excellent!

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2016 Bottle shared by Shane, thanks! Poured a very hazy yellowish gold with a white head that dissipated to the edges. Aroma was quite sour with a nice backing of brett funkiness. Flavor was a perfect balance of sour (particularly lemon) and brett funk that went down real nicely. A truly amazing beer.

Wow - the aroma of lemons, apricots, and that sharp tarty infected smell typical of spontaneous fermentation. It has a light golden orange color and thick body with almost no head. The flavor is super tart, with tons of grapefruit as described. It still manages to be as smooth as Russian River always does for such a tarty sour.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2010 realized that I had rated this as batch one - now corrected. I find this a little better. A barreld for 9 and additionally 19 month.  The appearence is corn-yellow with a tiny white head. The nose is citric like a gueuze. Melon and wild green grapes, some wet bread and butter. The taste is fresh with  a mild palate that have a milky touch. Streight forward without much complexiness. Wooden notes to follow this nice sour ale to the finish line

Crushed with CaryTheDude.  Thanks man!  Batch 2.  Pours golden with a thin whispy white head.  Aroma of strong lemon, hay, wet wool, horse blanket.  Favor of very dry, puckering sourness.  Lemon, wood, little bit of rubber.  Some funk.  Excellent.

Crushed with Honkeybra.  Aged for about 2 years.  Sour, kinda rubbery nose with other sour fruitiness.  Medium bodied mouthfeel with an excellent Bretty, sour flavor.  Another wonderful sour brew from Russian River.
Bottle. Golden-yellow colour with a white head. Aroma is sour, dry, brett, fruit. Flavour is sour, dry, brett, dust, oak , lemon. Nice beer.
Bottle (375 cl), thanks Marsiblursi. Murky orange, small white head. Cidery green apple aroma with clear notes of vinegar. Extremely sour, too much for my liking.

Bottle, 375ml corked. It pours a clear, golden body almost entirely without head. The aroma is funky, barnyardish with horse blanket and citrus. Lemony, fruty and funky flavor, sour finish. Smooth, medium bodied and astringent in the mouth. A very easy drinkable beer with a lovely aroma. 100326

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Batch 002

A: Golden orange. Relatively clear. Moderate fizzy head quickly receded with little lacing.

S: Sour lemons. Slight vinegar quality. Funky farmhouse nature. Some hay/wheat.

T: Incredibly sour. Lemons, grapefruit, vinegar, hay, yeast. Not much oak, which isnt surprising considering the age of the barrels used to age this guy.

M: Acidic. Sour. Certainly cleanses the palate of anything that might have been there before. Light bodied, and no sign of alcohol. Effervescent. 

O: Not as impressive as some of the other RR sours (consecration, supplication, temptation) but still quite nice.

This corked and caged bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a small sized head of foamy white colored bubbles that were and left behind a softly carbonated yellow orange colored body and a poor lacing. The aroma was lambic like and sour. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The strong flavor contained notes of sour and lambic like. An OK brew just nothing special and not worth the price I paid for it.

(750ml Bottle - Batch 003) Pours a golden color with a decent white head. Smell is very funky like cheese, sour lemons, apples, and oak. Taste is sour lemons, pears, apples, funk and oak. Medium mouthfeel, good carbonation, with a dry finish. Overall it is a great sour, though it did let me down a bit after all I had to go through to finally land a bottle.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle. 

Batch 003. The beer pours a hazy gold color with a white head. The aroma is much more funky than the other Russian River sours I have rated. I get some cheesy funk, a little tartness and some oak and vanilla. The flavor is more of the cheesy funk with some tart lemons and oak character. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Bottle. Batch 2.

Hazy pale orange color with a minimal off-white head that fizzes away.

The aroma is acidic and fruity. Very intense. Notes of cheese and dust, with a sharp lemon character. Very nice. 

The flavor is intensely sour with crystal clear lemon notes. Not as funky as the smell. Notes of grass and dust. Obvious cellar character with lovely barrel notes. The finish is bone dry and almost harshly sour. 

Medium body, fairly lively carbonation. 

This might be the most genuine American sour ale Ive come across. Very lambic-like in terms of sourness and overall character.

Batch 003 750ml bottle. poured slightly hazy golden with a meduim white head, which quickly faded. but left good lacing. aroma is tart citrus, some light hay notes. flavor is tart lemon up front light sweetness into the finish, which is crisp and smooth. Although I having trouble describing this as anything but lemony, it is not lacking complexity. I cant think of any way this could be improved, and i would love to try it next to  yellow bus or some of the other highly rated sour blondes, beacuse it hink this is hard to beat.

Part of a blind lambic tasting hosted by ryan.  This was my top rated beer in the tasting.  This and the other American beer, Duck Duck Gueuze definitely stood out compared with the others, but it was a distinction I enjoyed.   Poured a very pale straw yellow with a bit of a white head around the edges.  Very acidic on the aroma with noticeable oakiness.  Woody, earthy, and funky.  Slight sour fruit and berry aroma.  Over the top sourness, but thats something I like.  Lots of oak.  Fantastic beer.

Batch 003.

A- Body is a very cloudy (nearly opaque) hazy straw yellow. Pours with a hefty 2 finger+ foamy white head (it did gush some upon opening). Head retention is great...eventually fading to 1 finger and keeping that the rest of the way down.

S- The first thing that hits the nose is a big whiff of tart lemon. Lemon all over the place. Behind this is a very noticeable oak presence.

T- Much more wonderful and complex than the smell. Very tart and slightly sweet lemon zest is definitely the main character here. The acidic tartness puckers the lips slightly but a slight bready sweetness balances it out. The oak is definitely detectable but hides deep in the background and comes through a little more for the finish but never overshadows the main characters. What also comes forward for the finish is a saltiness. It finishes rather abruptly and is very dry-esp for a brew with a lower ABV.

M- Great medium to high carbonation and a light body with a balance of breadiness and citrus.

D- This was an excellent brew and one I would definitely trade for again. It ended a gathering with a few other BAs that turned out to be a Russian River night. These 3 beers (this deviation, and the younger) were definitely my favorite by this brewing co. so far and I look forward to trying other brews they have to offer.
